confusion_pairs.title: Spear phishing vs Whaling

a.definition: Targeted phishing aimed at specific individuals or teams with customized context.

b.definition: Targeted phishing aimed at senior executives (CEO/CFO), often involving urgent approvals or money.

bullets: Common lure: internal context vs urgent high-impact requests

confusion_pairs.title: Typosquatting vs Pharming

a.definition: Relies on user mistyping a URL and landing on a lookalike domain.

b.definition: Redirects users by altering name resolution (hosts file/DNS) or malware, even if URL was typed correctly.

bullets: Trigger: user typo vs DNS/hosts manipulation
Victim behavior: mistake required vs no mistake required
Defense: register typo domains vs secure DNS/endpoints

confusion_pairs.title: Brute force vs Password spraying

a.definition: Try many password guesses until one succeeds (often focused on a single account/target).

b.definition: Try one/few common passwords across many accounts to avoid lockout controls.

bullets: Pattern: many passwords → one account vs few passwords → many accounts
Lockouts: brute force triggers lockouts faster; spraying is designed to dodge them
Exam clue: 'common password across many users' → spraying

confusion_pairs.title: Online vs Offline password cracking

a.definition: Guesses are tried against a live login system with defenses (rate limits, lockouts, MFA).

b.definition: Attacker cracks stolen hashes locally; typically faster and stealthier than online guessing.

bullets: Defenses: online has lockouts/rate limits; offline usually does not
Speed: offline often faster if hashes are obtained
Detection: online creates auth logs; offline may not

confusion_pairs.title: Misinformation vs Disinformation

a.definition: False information spread without intent to mislead (often accidental).

b.definition: False information spread intentionally to mislead or manipulate.

bullets: Both can amplify via social media dynamics

se_authority.rule: If a request leans on role/title (“I’m the boss/IT/government”), treat it as untrusted until verified via a known channel.
se_authority.micro_example: Caller: “I’m HR—send employee SSNs now.” You: “I’ll call HR using the internal directory number.”

se_intimidation.rule: Threats (“you’ll be fired/arrested”) are a red flag. Real processes don’t require panic compliance.
se_intimidation.micro_example: Email: “Pay now or legal action.” You: report it; verify via official vendor contact.

se_social_proof.rule: ‘Everyone already did it’ is social proof bait. Verify independently; don’t follow the crowd.
se_social_proof.micro_example: Message: “All Finance clicked this link.” You: ask Finance lead via Teams, not the email link.

se_urgency.rule: Urgency is used to shut down thinking. Slow down, verify, then act.
se_urgency.micro_example: CEO ‘needs gift cards in 10 minutes’: verify with a call-back and approval workflow.

phishing.rule: Phishing tries to steal creds/info using deceptive messages—verify links and requests before acting.
phishing.micro_example: Email login prompt → open the site by typing the known URL, not clicking.

spear_phishing.rule: Customization (names, projects, teams) is a spear-phish tell—treat it as higher risk, not more trustworthy.
spear_phishing.micro_example: Invoice mentions your real vendor + project code → still verify via procurement system.

whaling.rule: Executive-targeted, high-impact requests are whaling—use strict verification and dual-approval.
whaling.micro_example: CFO email: “Wire funds now” → call CFO via known number + require second approver.

pretexting.rule: A believable story is not evidence. Verification beats storytelling every time.
pretexting.micro_example: ‘Vendor tech support’ wants remote access → verify ticket + vendor contact + scope.

bec.rule: BEC is email-driven fraud using legit-looking sender identities. Defend with MFA + training + payment verification controls.
bec.micro_example: New bank account details via email → verify by phone with vendor’s known number before paying.

typosquatting.rule: Typosquatting depends on human typing errors—watch domains carefully and use bookmarks/password managers.
typosquatting.micro_example: paypaI.com (capital i) vs paypal.com → don’t trust; retype official URL.

pharming.rule: Pharming can redirect you even when you type the correct URL—protect endpoints/DNS and watch certificate warnings.
pharming.micro_example: Correct URL but ‘certificate mismatch’ appears → stop; suspect DNS/hosts compromise.

password_spraying.rule: Spraying = few common passwords across many users to dodge lockouts; detect with unusual low-frequency attempts across accounts.
password_spraying.micro_example: One password attempted across 200 users overnight → spraying pattern.

brute_force.rule: Brute force = many guesses until success; stop with MFA, rate limiting, lockouts, and strong passwords.
brute_force.micro_example: 1 account gets 5,000 password attempts → brute force.

online_vs_offline.rule: Online attacks hit the login system; offline cracking happens after hashes are stolen—prevent hash theft and use strong hashing + salts.
online_vs_offline.micro_example: Stolen /etc/shadow dumped → attacker cracks offline with tools locally.

rainbow_tables.rule: Rainbow tables speed up cracking by looking up precomputed hashes—salts/peppers and strong hashing reduce their usefulness.
rainbow_tables.micro_example: Unsalted MD5 hashes → rainbow tables become highly effective.

hashing_basics.rule: Hashes are one-way; attackers crack by guessing plaintext and matching hashes, not by reversing.
hashing_basics.micro_example: Guess ‘Password123!’ → hash it → compare to stolen hash list.

salts_peppers.rule: Salt/pepper adds extra data before hashing so identical passwords don’t share the same hash, breaking precomputed lookup value.
salts_peppers.micro_example: Same password across users → different hashes due to unique salts.

mdm.rule: Disinformation is intentional deception; misinformation can be accidental. Use TRUST to respond as an organization.
mdm.micro_example: False rumor spreads online → publish verified facts + coordinate comms using TRUST steps.

trust_model.rule: TRUST = Tell, Ready, Understand, Strategize, Track. It’s your response playbook to MDM campaigns.
trust_model.micro_example: Tell the facts publicly, ready internal comms team, assess narrative, plan response, track impact.
